title: Linear and continuous functionals and norms

blocks.name: df-nmfn
blocks.content: Define the norm of a Hilbert space functional. (Contributed by NM, 11-Feb-2006.) (New usage is discouraged.)

blocks.name: df-nlfn
blocks.content: Define the null space of a Hilbert space functional. (Contributed by NM, 11-Feb-2006.) (New usage is discouraged.)

blocks.name: df-cnfn
blocks.content: Define the set of continuous functionals on Hilbert space. For every "epsilon" ( ` y ` ) there is a "delta" ( ` z ` ) such that... (Contributed by NM, 11-Feb-2006.) (New usage is discouraged.)
blocks.origin:
axiom df-cnfn(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4) {
  |- wceq(ccnfn, crab(s0, co(cc, cmap, chba), wral(s1, chba, wral(s2, crp, wrex(s3, crp, wral(s4, chba, wi(wbr(cfv(cno, co(cv(s4), cmv, cv(s1))), clt, cv(s3)), wbr(cfv(cabs, co(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s4)), cmin, cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), clt, cv(s2)))))))))
  -| diffss(s0, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s1, s4)
  -| diffss(s2, s4)
  -| diffss(s3, s4)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
}
blocks.pretty:
axiom df-cnfn(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4) {
  ⊢ ContFn = { s0 ∈(ℂ[↦]~H)| ∀(s1 ∈ ~H, ∀(s2 ∈ ℝ+, ∃(s3 ∈ ℝ+, ∀(s4 ∈ ~H,((normh `(s4[-h]s1))[<]s3 →(abs `((s0 ` s4)[-](s0 ` s1)))[<]s2)))))}
  ⊣ d(s0, s4)
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
  ⊣ d(s0, s2)
  ⊣ d(s0, s3)
  ⊣ d(s1, s4)
  ⊣ d(s2, s4)
  ⊣ d(s3, s4)
  ⊣ d(s1, s2)
  ⊣ d(s1, s3)
  ⊣ d(s2, s3)
}

blocks.name: df-lnfn
blocks.content: Define the set of linear functionals on Hilbert space. (Contributed by NM, 11-Feb-2006.) (New usage is discouraged.)
blocks.origin:
axiom df-lnfn(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3) {
  |- wceq(clf, crab(s0, co(cc, cmap, chba), wral(s1, cc, wral(s2, chba, wral(s3, chba, wceq(cfv(cv(s0), co(co(cv(s1), csm, cv(s2)), cva, cv(s3))), co(co(cv(s1), cmul, cfv(cv(s0), cv(s2))), caddc, cfv(cv(s0), cv(s3)))))))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
}
